repnme.cdata!: Papua New Guinea - Public Sector Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall assessment of the Papua New
            Guinea Public Sector Training Project is that the objectives
            were achieved satisfactorily. The lessons from the project
            include: 1) project management could be delegated to a lower
            operational level, providing a) sufficiently trained
            personnel are available and committed to the project; b) a
            strong project management committee directs policy and
            promotes the image of the project to Government and the
            general public; and c) appropriate financial management is
            available and practiced. 2) Much greater attention to
            cultural and social factors could assist management to plan
            and implement in a more timely manner, providing adequate
            provision is made for appropriate staffing and counterpart
            funding from the outset. 3) Project performance indicators,
            a mid-term review, stricter adherence to more detailed
            scheduling of events, and greater attention to monitoring
            and evaluation throughout the life of the project could
            reduce the implementation delays. 4) Clearer definition and
            understanding of Borrower and the Bank procedures for
            financial management, as well as trained personnel to
            implement them could allow more effective disbursement. 5)
            National procurement procedures could be simplified by the
            Government. 6) Government departments could plan for
            sustaining project activities both during and after the
            project. 7) Flexibility is essential throughout the life of
            any project.

repnme.cdata!: Papua New Guinea - Public Sector Training Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the project are to
            strengthen in-service training in the public and private
            sectors and increase the supply of specialized high-level
            personnel to staff the Government's policy and planning
            agencies and meet personnel shortages in technical fields.
            Specifically the project will: (a) support the
            implementation of the National Training Policy (NTP) through
            strengthening the capacity of the Department of Personnel
            Management (DPM) to promote, coordinate, monitor and
            evaluate training in the public sector and strengthen the
            capacity of the Department of Labor and Employment (DLE) to
            play a similar role in the private sector; (b) upgrade and
            reorient the Administrative College (Adcol) towards its new
            role as defined under the NTP namely to focus on short,
            intensive skill development courses and executive
            development programs and place greater emphasis on research,
            curriculum development and the training of trainers; and (c)
            finance an overseas fellowship program for training in
            policy and planning fields and in specific technical fields
            which is not presently available.  The project will finance
            civil works, equipment, teaching and consumable materials,
            fellowships and experts.
